<div id="csl-bib-meta-FX3Q5EPI" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-FX3Q5EPI" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Blom conducted a five-year study in the Hallingskarven mountain range in southern Norway to explore ecological awareness through direct experience of the environment. They focused on how being physically present in nature can make people feel connected, vulnerable, and part of the ecosystem. Using diary notes, visuals, sound recordings, and literature, Blom aimed to enhance the ability to notice and find meaning in the changing environment. The study also examined how technology like photography and video can either help or hinder this awareness. By creating sonic and audiovisual artworks, Blom found that the creative process can deepen reflection and contribute to understanding ecological awareness. This research highlights the importance of sensory experiences and artistic expression in fostering a deeper connection to nature.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-FX3Q5EPI" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Ecological Awareness, Sensibilisation, Mountain Experience, Recording Technology, Artistic Articulation
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-FX3Q5EPI" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    Based on process philosophy and ecological philosophy, the project explores ecological awareness in the experience of a mountain. The fieldwork takes place at Tvergasteinstj√∏rnet, a mountain area located in Hallingskarven mountain range in southern Norway, over a period of approximately five years. The research aim is to explore, experience and artistically articulate the mountain. This includes the experience of ecological awareness or the sense of being embedded, being part of and being vulnerable. This is art- and practice research where knowledge develops in the interplay between theory, practice and art production. Here, the body and the senses are the primary sources of knowledge. Sensibilisation is to enhance the ability to discern and find meaning in the continuously changing nuances of the environment, and this is both method and aim. Diary notes, visuals and sound recordings, together with readings of literature enhance sensibilisation and awarness. The project explores in what way recording technology, photography, sound and video, facilitates, or distorts awareness of the mountain. Sonic and audiovisual artworks are developed the along the way. The project discusses the use recording technology in a way that enhances ecological awareness. The creative process stimulates reflection and the artistic outcomes contribute to the research findings.
  </article>
